newsitem.title: FRANCE: France Telecom says swap wld help alliance.
newsitem.headline: France Telecom says swap wld help alliance.

text.p: The chairman of France Telecom has said a share swap with Germany's Deutsche Telekom would bolster an alliance between the two operators but depends on the new French government's stance on privatisation.

France Telecom chairman Michel Bon said in an interview with the Journal du Dimanche newspaper released on Saturday that a share swap was topical because of Bonn's agreement last month to sell some of its remaining shares in Deutsche Telekom.
"Such an exchange would reinforce our alliance with them (Deutsche Telekom)," Bon said. "But this operation depends on the government's decision on opening up France Telecom."

Deutsche Telekom said last month it had entered negotiations with France Telecom over a possible share swap but the French operator immediately denied this, saying there were only informal but regular discussions.

Privatisations are a sensitive issue for France's new Socialist-led government, which has already run into fierce conservative opposition attack over its decision on Friday to scrap the sale of defence contractor Thomson-CSF.

The six-week-old government is now weighing whether to go ahead with the previous centre-right government's plans for a partial selloff of France Telecom. It has hinted this sale may go ahead if staff are consulted and agree first.
The planned sale of a minority 30 to 35 percent public stake worth around 50 billion francs was suspended after the left's upset victory in parliamentary elections on June 1.
Bon declined to comment in the interview on the merits of privatisation, saying this was a matter for the government.
He has previously been quoted as saying the suspension of the sale last month was a setback but not a catastrophe.

White-collar workers at France Telecom favour the selloff but the Communist-backed CGT union is firmly against any privatisations. The Communists are junior partners in Socialist Prime Minister Lionel Jospin's government.
Deutsche Telekom said last month it had reached an agreement with the German government allowing Bonn to sell some of its remaining shares in the company to strategic investors.
Both countries' plans were drawn up to help shape up their finances for European monetary union starting in 1999.

An exchange of shares between France Telecom and Deutsche Telekom would build on a strategic alliance known as Atlas and bring the two groups closer together at a time when European operators are getting ready for full competition next year.
